headline.main: Drugs to Spur New Cells, And Without the Politics

docs.abstract: Several biotechnology companies work to develop drugs that stimulate brain and other organs to grow new cells and self-repair; drugs avoid rejection of cells and tissues by body's immune system; they avoid surgery usually needed to implant new cells; and they sidestep political and philosophical barbs attached to cloning and stem cell research; some regenerative drugs are in late-stage trials; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: As debate again heats up over cloning and stem cell research, several biotechnology companies are trying to develop a far less controversial approach to cell regeneration. The companies are actively working on drugs that stimulate the brain and other organs to grow new cells and repair themselves.

headline.main: As Acid Reflux Cases Rise, Doctors Are Asking Why

docs.abstract: Researchers say that incidence of cases of gastroesophageal reflux, technical name for what happens when digesting food and stomach acid pass up into esophagus through sphincter muscle at top of stomach, are rising; doctors do not fully understand what causes acid reflux; suggested causes of rising incidence include shifts in diet toward fattier foods, higher rates of obesity, and aggressive treatment of ulcers; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In 1993, right out of college, Maura Donovan began to feel sick to her stomach periodically throughout the day. She had a burning sensation in her chest and cramps that were at their worst every morning after breakfast. Occasionally, when she went out for pizza and beer or Chinese food with friends, the pain got even worse. ''After a while,'' she said, ''I felt vaguely sick and sort of miserable all the time. People thought I was nuts.''
